title: What makes a guitar riff good? - Quora

response.answer_text: The very same elements that make riffs like the ones found in songs like Johnny B. Goode, Satisfaction, Foxey Lady, Purple Haze, Won’t get fooled again, Substitute, Helter Skelter, Whole Lotta Love, Smoke on the Water, Mississippi Queen, Iron Man, Cat Scratch Fever, Back in Black, Crazy Train, Let’s Go Crazy, Barracuda, Rainbow In The Dark, Enter Sandman, Smells like Teen Spirit, contain the answers you seek. What are those key elements that constitute a good, or great guitar riff? Does it immediately grab your ear? Is it catchy and memorable? Does it have a groove or pulse that makes you want to move body, or compel you to pull out the old air guitar and start jumping around like a monkey? Can you sing it in your head, even if you haven’t heard it in years? A good guitar riff is akin to a tribal loop. Not too long, and not too short. You’ll know it when you hear it, but great guitar riffs are hooks unto themselves, because they hook the listeners attention into its hypnotic tractor beam, so to speak. Without knowing your knowledge and experience on guitar, as well as your general musical knowledge, I think I’ll stop here. Were you one of my guitar students, those elements would be further expanded upon with guitarist exclusive vernacular, techniques, devices, tonal elements and the like. Happy Riffing.

I agree with all the other answers (particularly the quote from Jimmy Page). I’ll only add this, particularly oriented towards younger players… rhythm! Many, many electric guitarists forget about rhythm. They think that riffs and solos are all about how fast you can wiggle your fingers. No, particularly with riffs, it’s about really sitting in the groove. One (under-appreciated) example: the main riff from “Can’t You Hear Me Knocking”. Keith Richards is the king of riffs although he’s hardly the king of solos. Listen to how that particular riff really sits in the groove of the song, with that bluesy, back of the beat quality to it. Keith always did way more for the Stones’ rhythm section than Bill Wyman ever did.

totally simple, 1. does it sound cool to you- it can be simple- it can be complex, it can last 3 seconds or an hour. most remembered riffs are simple (satisfaction, smoke on the water) to more complex , however it is not mega brain science most of the time. then 2. practice it a few dozen times 3. get at least 3 others who have a brain, heart, and any sense of rhythm at all to listen to it- either live or recorded. 4. get their opinions Then with the opinions of four good human brains you can decide to share it one on one the rest of your life-(I am doing that for about 150 riffs) or go big time. 5. it takes more than one riff to make a great living with music- i know a lot of people who have great riffs and make a little, make a modest or make a nothing. Still people need music- go for it- dont quit your day job yet!

Short answer: You know. You just know. ;-) Longer answer: Pretty much the same as the other commenters. A guitar riff is a good example of a 'hook'; that is, something in the song that catches the listener's attention, i.e., it 'hooks' them. Think of songs that start with a strong riff: 'Smoke On The Water', 'Satisfaction', 'Day Tripper', 'Johnny B. Goode', etc. You KNOW the song INSTANTLY! It pulls you into it RIGHT AWAY! And the song builds from there! And then, you pick up your guitar and try to play it; because the riff is fairly simple, you can do it, and you get a sense of accomplishment! Honest. Listen to Beethoven's 5th Symphony; “Da-da-da-DAAAH!” is a killer riff, even if it's NOT rock music! If you want to create a good riff, come up with something CATCHY!

The Supreme Court ruled on obscenity many years ago saying something to the effect of: “…can’t define obscenity but know it when we see it…” Good riff is the same - hard to define but we know it when we hear it. For me, it is about the rhythm, progression, structure, tone and “pepper” that each individual brings to their style. Mostly listen to metal and 40’s tunes myself. Good rhythm guitar players are king. Think Malcolm Young - AC/DC - arguably one of the best.

Lots of valid points here, good stuff. But as opposed to trying to fulfill a set of criteria or formula thing out, I suggest that our recently departed brother Lemmy of Motorhead may have summed it up as well as it could be said…wanna know? Quote- “if you think youve got something, run it up the flagpole and see if anybody salutes…” after all, the reaction of the intended audiance is going to be the determing factor in the end right? Good shot Lemmy, RIP.

Lots of good answers. There's definitely a "you know it when you hear it" quality to it, but here are a few general commonalities that I hear in many of the great riffs: It's simple. Most are only a few notesIt uses some combination of repetition and noveltyIt has a strong rhythmic componentIf you sit down with a guitar with those basic ideas in mind, you're on a good path to creating a memorable riff.

It’s Memorable. Short, simple and something any non-musician can hum, whistle, and use for a ringtone. If your Uncle Herman who’s a plumber and never touched a musical instrument can hear your riff and play it back to you on a kazoo, you’ve got a hit! Just add a very simple chorus (“I Can’t Get No Satisfaction” for example) and then fill in the verses with gibberish.
The instant catchiness of it. The moment it comes on, the inexplicable need to play on an air guitar, just rock out to it, or simply put, zone out into your own world.

Chuck Berry: intro to Johnny B Goode. It is the seminal guitar riff. Every rocker at some point has played it, tried to play it, or used bits and pieces of it in their own version of an intro or solo. Jimmy Page adapted it for his guitar break in Stairway to Heaven. Everything Chuck played in that song is adaptable. Hail Hail Rock and Roll!

response.answer_text: Actually, I prefer to avoid riffs, per se. Instead, try to cleave to playing “lines,” musical statements. Riffs are great for practice, and, knowing some, you are likely to find times that they can be a part of your musical statements, but don’t just play riffs. Have something to say. A few well-chosen words are more effective than packing as many words as possible into a paragraph.

Groovy rhythm.Simple melody.It conveys the proper mood (angry or relaxed or even romantic).It can be played by someone who holds the guitar for the first time in his life (everyone had tried Smoke on the Water).
'A great riff is something you know instinctively. It has energy and attitude and sex.' - Jimmy Page (Led Zeppelin)
Since there is no universal agreement on what constitutes a good guitar riff, there is no meaningful answer to this question.
The perspective of the listener. Something only has value if the recipeint deems it to have value to them. I don't like the riff to smoke on the water… but many others do. That is a perfect example.
